titleproper.value: Guide to the Frank Schonfeld Papers <num>WAG.027</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Ted Casselman and Jane Latour, circa 1997, and Gail Malmgreen and Wendy Scheir, 2005. Finding aid was edited by Maggie Schreiner for compliance with DACS and Tamiment Required Elements for Archival Description and to reflect the incorporation of nonprint materials in December 2013. Box 44 added (2014)

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-16T13:46:26</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

extent.value: in 43 record cartons and 2 manuscript boxes

abstract.value: Frank Schonfeld was born in 1916, and died in 2011. After some training as a rabbi, he studied in the Social Action program at the New School. After World War II service in the Merchant Marines, he joined Local 1011 of the Painters union in 1945. In 1961, Schonfeld ran for secretary-treasurer of Brotherhood of Painters District Council 9 (New York City). He lost and the winning Rarback administration sued him for libel. He then launched a public campaign to clean up corruption in the union. Blocked from running in 1964, in 1966 he ran for secretary-treasurer and won. He held office for two terms, during which time he carried out a number of reforms to combat union corruption. In 1972, he was found guilty by a union trial board on charges later determined to be unfounded. Schonfeld's campaign to end union corruption led to the eventual indictments of key leaders. This collection provides an inside view of a trade distinguished by highly volatile employment cycles, corrupt practices, and successive waves of different ethnic groups making up the workforce. It includes correspondence, flyers, election materials, legal documents, agreements, bulletins, photographs and clippings.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Frank Schonfeld Papers; WAG 027; box number; folder number; <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library <lb/>70 Washington Square South <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.

An additional box of photographs and artifacts was donated by David Schonfeld, Frank's son, in 2007. The accession number associated with these materials is 2014.119. In 2014, David donated his father's unpublished manuscript; the accession number associated with this gift is 2014.154 and the materials have been added to the collection as Series XXI.

After retiring from the union in 1982, Schonfeld remained very active in political and community affairs, serving on the board of the Amalgamated Housing Corporation as treasurer, while studying and volunteering at Lehman College in the Bronx, and working with Herman Benson and the Association for Union Democracy. He died on November 2, 2011.

This collection consists of correspondence, minutes, financial reports, an unpublished manuscript, drafts and statements of materials by Louis Weinstock and Frank Schonfeld, and litigation records of District Council 9 (DC9). Also included in the collection are documents from internal trials, minutes of meetings of the board of trustees, materials relating to the amalgamation of locals, election records and materials from various rank-and-file groups spearheaded by Schonfeld. Newspaper clippings, by-law and referenda campaign materials, and collective bargaining agreements give further insight into the internal disputes within DC 9. Approximately 200 black and white photographs document the 1968 strike, as well as the general membership and officials of the Local. Also included in this collection are materials pertaining to the California Painters Local 4 and proceedings of the New York State Conference of Painters and the International Brotherhood of Painters.

Schonfeld, Trusteeship (Hearings)197768Documents of F. Schonfeld197769Trusteeship (Damery): DC 91990-1991610Series VI: Litigation Records1960-1990Scope and Content Note

Includes the Santos-Woodfinishers case, a jurisdictional fight with the Carpenters, and corrupt practices of District Council 9 leaders involving the transfer of work and jurisdiction of their own membership to competing unions in return for favors. Applications for wiretaps and progress reports issued to the court provide a wealth of information on corruption within DC 9. Additional materials, including press releases and rank-and-file flyers, reflect the complex course of events within DC 9 that landed it in the courts.

Dixon; Petition to Master Painters, NYC, Against Judgment1973925J and M Gonzalez Painting Co.; DC 9 and 32B-32J: Stipulation and Order; NLRB1978926Series VIII: Insurance Funds1938-1994Scope and Content Note

Includes minutes of meetings of the board of trustees and related materials, including reports and publicity prepared by the opposition in efforts to expose the corrupt activities of the Fund managers. Simon Kesselman's correspondence, centering on mismanagement of the Painters annuity funds, illustrates the issues that fueled members' staunch opposition to the District leadership.

Includes materials related to the contentious atmosphere that pervaded relations between District Council 9 and its many locals. Disagreements often reflect the three major factions in the union, the Progressives, the Rank-and-File, and the reform platform organized by Frank Schonfeld.

Includes documentation on Dow Wilson's leadership in Painters Local 4, the strike he conducted, the campaign against him, and the murders and subsequent resolutions in tribute to him. The series also includes correspondence between Schonfeld and Wilson, documenting their mutual attempts to interest the leadership of the Painters Union and the AFL-CIO in a clean-up campaign.

Includes materials on anti-member activities within the union. Examples include documents on the Paperhangers Local 490 strike, wherein the District Council asserted, "There is no strike," and encouraged the membership to cross Local 490's picket lines; and the Woodfinishers Strike opposing the corrupt bargaining efforts of leadership.

Includes standard items issued by the union, both NYC and the International, as well as background material on issues documented in other series in this collection, such as the Maintenance Mechanics (see also the Inter-Local Caucus Election Materials) and various materials from the Schonfeld administration. A historically significant document in this series is the 1909 statement on an injunction.
